name: 1H-pyrazole-5-methanol, 3-methyl-
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3901
Reason: 1H-pyrazole-5-methanol has a melting point that we can compare to benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of a methyl group linked in a linear fashion. The methyl group introduces a rigid structure, which can participate in hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point by approximately +10°C. Additionally, the pyrazole ring introduces a rigid structure, which can participate in hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point by approximately +20°C. The methyl group also introduces a bulky side chain, which can sterically hinder the crystal lattice, raising the melting point by approximately +10°C.
